poem:
Title: "On Interest and Time"

The Bank meanders,
through surpluses large, unspent,
rate-cuts pending in crimson dusk.
Dhingra speaks in ink and numbers,
warning with a dovish voice,
the cost of delay is more than coins,
but pulse of the economic heart.
Each tick tied to tender inflation,
the fee of waiting
is a silent crescendo,
unseen, unheard,
until it echoes in empty coffers.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "BoE’s Dhingra warns against delaying interest rate cuts; ‘limited room’ for tax cuts after record UK budget surplus – as it happened 3.48pm GMT Closing post Time to recap… Bank of England policymaker Swati Dhingra has warned that there are real economic costs to delaying interest rate cuts until we see more signs that underlying inflation pressures are easing. Dhingra, the most dovish rate-setter at the BOE, warned that delaying interest-rate cuts comes at a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
